title: As a recently admitted transfer student to an expensive school, what are the best options to find available scholarships? - Quora
tags: College and University Scholarship and Fellowships

response.answer_text: Thank you for taking the time to read my question. I look forward to reading any helpful insight and sage advice that might be offered. My situation is fairly straight forward, after retiring from the military, yours truly grew tired of going to work at places like St Paul Island, Alaska, and Afghanistan to make good money. As a gift to myself, I vowed to break away from my long career in meteorology to pursue a creative path. Thus, I decided to quit my NATO job, go back to school. After completing an Associates degree, I applied to two schools, both great, schools and one is considered as a public Ivy School (UNC at Chapel Hill’s School of Media and Journalism) and the other is a private Ivy (Columbia). As a veteran, my education benefits are sublime, but to attend Columbia, I need to look at every option available to ensure not racking up a substantial school debt. The challenge I currently face is that nearly most online scholarship search pages (that I’ve encountered) seem more about advertisements or creating subscription accounts and not all that useful to check for the availability of scholarships. Therefore, to narrow down my search, does anyone have any advice on the best avenues to pursue learning about the seemingly infinite number of academic scholarships available? Thank you for both your time and consideration, Darrell

Go to the school’s financial aid office. They will know. After my military service, I had so many scholarships and low interest loans that I was making money. I even collected unemployment insurance from NY State for having been “fired” from the U.S. army.
Did you talk with the financial aid counselor? They know the school and they know the system with respect to financial aid, including loans and scholarships.
